blog.name: imagines-to-quench-thirst
blog.title: Imagines for my unquenchable thirst
blog.description:
Hello, welcome to my personal heaven of imagines. Please, step in and enjoy. P.S. if you want send some requests

-V

summary: Imagine: Thor watching the birth of your child and trying to calm himself
body:
Imagine: Thor watching the birth of your child and trying to calm himself

‘You can do it! You are great!’

‘Thor, you have… said that to me already.’

‘Oh, I wasn’t telling you that, it was for me, Stark said if I said that the confidence will surge right up.’

‘Thor, I think that Tony was talking about… another kind of confidence.’

title: Bingo Sign-Ups Closing
body:
Sign-ups close today! The link to the form can be found HERE! For more information visit our rules and timeline and FAQ page. Thank you to all those who have already signed up!

Cards will be sent out within the coming week! :)

Just to clarify since we’ve been asked: The sign-up form will remain available after today, however, your card will come from a pre-generated pool and may not have your specific preferences on it.

title: Captain Marvel: Over-powered Mary Sue?
body:
There’s been a lot of criticism surrounding the MCU’s latest blockbuster Captain Marvel. Many people have described the lead character, Carol Danvers, as “bland” or “too perfect,” to argue or prove she’s “just a Mary Sue,” but are these claims true or fair?

“Mary Sue” is a prevalent and critical label applied to many strong female characters, and while it carries clear negative connotations, it can be difficult to determine what characteristics are actually related to Mary-Sueism, since the term is often misused to downplay the importance or relevance of fictional women and their accomplishments inside a story or their value as role models for real women.

Mary Sues can be identified by at least one or (more likely) a combination of the following characteristics:

i. They serve as authorial wish fulfillment. The character is an idealized version of their creator; this may pertain to physical appearance or to personal experiences, struggles, flaws, or quirks. They may alternatively be the creator’s idea of a perfect significant other.

ii. They are the best in every, or almost every, way for no believable reason. The character is super-intelligent, breathtakingly good-looking, in peak physical condition, and masters things easily.

iii. They are unique in appearance for no believable reason. The character’s physique or features sets them apart from the rest of their species with no explanation and often without a plot-relevant purpose.

iv. They are always right. The character may have flaws, but the flaws are displayed only when they make the character look good. The character may also correctly predict or guess story events without proof or indication these events will or did happen.

At its core, true Mary-Sueism is about specialness and perfection. Now here’s the real question: does Captain Marvel fit this bill?

The favorite argument to support the “Captain Marvel is a Mary Sue” position is “she’s over-powered.” She isn’t “over-powered,” she’s powerful. She has super strength, flight, and photon blasts, but she’s not invulnerable. Enemies could research and develop better tech to withstand her attacks and better weapons with which to attack her. Her fight scenes in the movie’s climax were easily won because her power was unanticipated. She likely won’t have that advantage anymore.

Additionally, if we run Captain Marvel through the characteristics of a Mary Sue that were listed previously, we’ll find that:

i. She is obviously not the work of authorial wish fulfillment.

ii. She is not the best at everything, or even most things. She’s a fighter with immense power, but she worked hard and for many years to become adept in this area, and the movie never portrays her as effortlessly multitalented.

iii. She has no inexplicably unusual physical attributes.

iv. She isn’t always right, and she doesn’t always have the right assumptions, ideas, or attitude going into a situation.

Even if you agree she isn’t a Mary Sue but maintain she “still has no flaws” or “still has no personality” you are still wrong. She’s aggressive, impetuous, headstrong, and invasive, but she’s also passionate, brave, supportive, and forthright. That’s far from flawless and bland.

It’s true that she didn’t have to learn to be a better person like Iron Man or Thor did in their movies, but that isn’t the only way of providing a protagonist with a struggle. Captain Marvel followed a route more similar to Captain America and Black Panther: their stories weren’t focused on overcoming a glaring personal flaw, but they all embarked on a journey in which they learned to unapologetically express themselves and become the hero, the leader, they wanted to see in the world. That was the personal struggle they grew from.

It’s understandable if you’re not interested in that kind of storyline, but to try and argue that its implementation indicates the main character inherently has no depth is ludicrous and, in the case of these three characters, clearly untrue.

In conclusion, Captain Marvel is neither over-powered nor a Mary Sue. Does that mean you have to like or relate to her character? Not at all, but you can express that opinion without dismissing her impact or reducing her character to “a bland, over-powered Mary Sue.”

title: Monomythic Screenwriting, Episode 9: Character
body:
In this episode of Monomythic, we go over character construction and use a Monomythic structure of characterization based on Jungian archetypes.

In this screenwriting lesson, I discuss character: What are the different archetypes using Monomythic structure, the difference between wants versus needs of your character, and how to make a fiction character feel independent.

WHY EMPATHY MATTERS

Movies are about empathy. They are gateways into untapped feelings that start at the screenplay, and end at the journey onscreen. Movies communic…

View On WordPress

In this screenwriting lesson, I discuss character: What are the different archetypes using Monomythic structure, the difference between wants versus needs of your character, and how to make a fiction character feel independent.

WHY EMPATHY MATTERS

Movies are about empathy. They are gateways into untapped feelings that start at the screenplay, and end at the journey onscreen. Movies communic…

trail.content_raw:
In this episode of Monomythic, we go over character construction and use a Monomythic structure of characterization based on Jungian archetypes.
